issue.body:
Hi,

I have deployed istio on AKS cluster and trying to route the traffic from Azure load balancer to pods/service ( grpc/http/2 ) residing on AKS cluster through istio ingress gateway. 

As per documentation ( https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/traffic-management/ingress/ingress-control/ ), I have created gateway, Virtual service. All the components are up and running. However, I am unable to access the service via external load balancer. Please find below my yaml files -

**service.yml** :

apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: myApp-service
  namespace: myApp-service
  labels:
    app: myApp-service
spec:
  ports:
  - port: 80
    targetPort: 80
    name: grpc
  selector:
    app: app

**virtual-service.yaml :**

apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: myApp-service-vs
spec:
  hosts:
  - "my-app-service.xyzdomain.com"
  gateways:
  - istio-system/myApp-service-gateway
  http:
  - match:
    - port: 8443
    timeout: 30s
    route:
    - destination:
        port:
          number: 80
        host: myApp-service

**istio-gateway.yaml**

apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: Gateway
metadata:
  name: myApp-service-gateway
spec:
  selector:
    istio: istio-ingressgateway-myapp
  servers:
  - hosts:
    - my-app-service.xyzdomain.com
    port:
      name: https
      number: 8443
      protocol: HTTPS
    tls:
      credentialName: myApp-service
      mode: SIMPLE
	  
**ingress-gateway.yaml**

apiVersion: install.istio.io/v1alpha1
kind: IstioOperator
metadata:
  name: istio-ingressgateway-myapp
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  components:
    ingressGateways:
      - name: istio-ingressgateway-myapp
        enabled: true
        label:
            istio: istio-ingressgateway-myapp
            app: istio-ingressgateway-myapp
        k8s:
          serviceAnnotations:
            service.beta.kubernetes.io/azure-load-balancer-internal: "true"
          hpaSpec:
            maxReplicas: 2
            minReplicas: 2
          service:
            ports:
            - port: 8443
              targetPort: 8443
              name: myapp-https            
            - port: 15021             
              targetPort: 15021
              name: status-port
            - port: 80             
              targetPort: 8080
              name: http2
            - port: 443             
              targetPort: 8443
              name: https
            - port: 15443             
              targetPort: 15443
              name: tls
			  
Application pods are residing in the namespace : myApp-service and labelled with istio-injection-enabled. App is built on grpc - http2 protocol. While I hit the application URL, IT gives me below error -

2022-08-22T14:39:40.198050Z	info	xdsproxy	connected to upstream XDS server: istiod.istio-system.svc:15012
[2022-08-22T14:45:02.293Z] "POST /<applicationMethod>/Login HTTP/2" 200 UR upstream_reset_before_response_started{remote_reset} - "-" 5 0 49 - "<ip_for_node_in_nodepool>" "grpc-dotnet/2.36.0.0" "dcec6426-f029-9f13-b366-e23953e3ddf9" "my-app-service.xyzdomain.com:8443" "<application_pod_ip>:80" inbound|80|| 127.0.0.6:47961 <application_pod_ip>:80 <ip_for_node_in_noepool>:0 outbound_.80_._.myApp-service.myApp-service.svc.cluster.local default

DNS -> Internal Azure load balancer -> istio ingress gateway -> service on AKS.

When I hit the service through curl or browser, It gives same error. Following are the current versions of the components.

AKS Version - 1.23.5
istio version - 1.14.3

We have similar set up running on the older version of AKS/istio.

AKS : 1.20.13
istio : 1.7.3

Not sure what's wrong with current set up on latest versions and how do I debug. Any pointers to start troubleshooting ? OR may be I am missing any potential changes in latest istio version.

Please let me know if any information needed from my side and suggest if any idea on above error.

issue.title: HTTP2 \ gRPC metrics

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

I've been looking for any HTTP2 \ gRPC specific metrics exposed by the istio ingress gateway and istio-proxy sidecars, wasn't able find any:
- the `envoy_cluster_http2_*` doesn't seem to reflect current state: `envoy_cluster_http2_streams_active` always shows 1 while there are certainly more active streams, `envoy_cluster_http2_pending_send_bytes` and `envoy_cluster_http2_outbound_flood` while I'm getting logs for "response_code_details":"http2.outbound_frames_flood" events;
- the `istio_request_messages_total` and `istio_response_messages_total` are not exposed on the metrics endpoint at all (while tons of other HTTP metrics are exposed as expected);

Is this a bug or there there is any additional undocumented configuration required on the istio \ envoy part to get subject exposed?

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.11.3
control plane version: 1.13.5
data plane version: 1.13.5 (12 proxies)
$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.23.3
Server Version: v1.22.11
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: TCP Traffic not always routed to correct namespace/subdomain

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

i am not 100% sure this is a bug as i may just be missing something on the implementation. when using multiple namespaces, all of which use the same port. incoming traffic will stick with the first one connected even when trying to disable the connection and connect to a different namespace/subdomain.

subdomain1.domain.com:5591  ----> TCP connection internet endpoint 
subdomain2.domain.com:5591  

attempt to switch to subdomain2 fails. 

subdomain1.domain.com:5591  
subdomain2.domain.com:5591  ----> TCP connection internet endpoint attempted, but doesn't work

Traffic is not routed unless I manually change to unique ports via kubectl edit....

subdomain1.domain.com:5592
subdomain2.domain.com:5591  ----> TCP connection internet endpoint works now.

So, it is almost as if istio ignores the subdomain for TCP and just relies on unique ports. 

Gateway and VirtualService info in 'Additional Info' section.



### Version

```prose
[opc@tf4-operator ~]$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.21.6+2.el8
Server Version: v1.22.5
[opc@tf4-operator ~]$ 
[opc@tf4-operator ~]$ helm version --short
v3.6.3+g809dabc
```


### Additional Information

not using istioctl

issue.body:
### Bug Description

I have 2 VMs (nfs client and nfs server) that has been integrated into the Istio service mesh (Control Plane running in kubernetes). issue.title: StatefulSets Peer Discovery

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

I have a RabbitMQ cluster running in Kubernetes. It works as expected without the Istio injection enabled.
Unfortunately, the cluster crashes when the istio-injection is enabled. This is caused by the peer discovery failure during the startup process. I got the following error in the pod logs:

```
2022-06-23 12:39:59.907 [error] <0.249.0> CRASH REPORT Process <0.249.0> with 0 neighbours exited with reason: no match of right hand value {error,eacces} in rabbit_peer_discovery_k8s:make_request/0 line 110 in application_master:init/4 line 138
```

Please bear in mind that:
- Istio version: 1.14.0
- Deployment via Istio operator
- Tested with both mTLS enabled/disabled

I created a service entry per pod, and expose all ports that are needed - telling istio that they are inside the service mesh, example of a ServiceEntry In rabbitMQ - this looks like this:
```
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  labels:
    app: rabbitmq-ha
    chart: rabbitmq-ha-1.12.1
    heritage: Tiller
    release: rabbitmq
  name: rabbitmq
  namespace: rabbitns
spec:
  hosts:
  - rabbitmq-0.rabbitmq-discovery.rabbitns.svc.cluster.local
  - rabbitmq-1.rabbitmq-discovery.rabbitns.svc.cluster.local
  location: MESH_INTERNAL
  ports:
  - name: http
    number: 15672
    protocol: TCP
  - name: amqp
    number: 5672
    protocol: TCP
  - name: epmd
    number: 4369
    protocol: TCP
  - name: amqps
    number: 5671
    protocol: TCP
  - name: exporter
    number: 9419
    protocol: TCP
  - name: inter-node
    number: 25672
    protocol: TCP
  resolution: NONE
```

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.14.0
control plane version: 1.14.0
data plane version: 1.14.0 (3 proxies)
$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.21.5
Server Version: v1.22.4
```


### Additional Information

Analysis Report:
```
Error [IST0106] (ServiceEntry rabbitmq-istio-test/rabbitmq) Schema validation error: multiple hosts provided with non-HTTP, non-TLS ports
```

issue.title: pilot-discovery periodically reads server disk data, resulting in high IO

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

labels.name: feature/Virtual-machine
labels.description: issues related with VM support

issue.body:
### Bug Description

I deployed istio on the k8s cluster, using istiooperator.
Istiooperator is configured as follows:
````
spec:
  components:
    ingressGateways:
    - enabled: true
      k8s:
        env:
        - name: ISTIO_META_OWNER
          value: kubernetes://apis/apps/v1/namespaces/istio-system/daemonsets/istio-ingressgateway
        nodeSelector:
          istio-ingressgateway: "true"
        overlays:
        - kind: Deployment
          name: istio-ingressgateway
          patches:
          - path: kind
            value: DaemonSet
          - path: spec.template.spec.hostNetwork
            value: true
          - path: spec.template.spec.dnsPolicy
            value: ClusterFirstWithHostNet
          - path: spec.strategy
        resources:
          limits:
            cpu: "2"
            memory: 2Gi
          requests:
            cpu: "2"
            memory: 2Gi
      name: istio-ingressgateway
    pilot:
      k8s:
        nodeSelector:
          istio-ingressgateway: "true"
  meshConfig:
    accessLogEncoding: JSON
    accessLogFile: /dev/stdout
    defaultConfig:
      tracing:
        sampling: 1
    discoverySelectors:
    - matchLabels:
        istio-discovery: "true"
    enableTracing: true
  profile: default
````
The status of the deployment is as follows:
````
# kubectl get po -n istio-system -owide
NAME                         READY   STATUS    RESTARTS       AGE    IP               NODE                         NOMINATED NODE   READINESS GATES
istio-ingressgateway-27gcd   1/1     Running   1 (2d4h ago)   2d5h   10.0.0.24      k8snode24   <none>           <none>
istio-ingressgateway-42q59   1/1     Running   0              2d5h   10.0.0.25      k8snode25   <none>           <none>
istio-ingressgateway-kfs7n   1/1     Running   0              2d5h   10.0.0.28      k8snode28   <none>           <none>
istio-ingressgateway-kj4k6   1/1     Running   0              2d5h   10.0.0.27      k8snode27   <none>           <none>
istio-ingressgateway-qnzbn   1/1     Running   0              2d5h   10.0.0.26      k8snode26   <none>           <none>
istiod-7695b997c9-q2vbp      1/1     Running   0              4d5h   172.20.183.237   k8snode27   <none>           <none>
istiod-7695b997c9-tbbwm      1/1     Running   0              8d     172.30.170.130   k8snode26   <none>           <none>
istiod-7695b997c9-wtjrb      1/1     Running   1 (8d ago)     8d     172.27.201.144   k8snode25   <none>           <none>
````
But the pilot-discovery on the k8snode26 node is often very high iowait.This node only deploys istio-ingressgateway, calico, kube-proxy, containerd, kubelet.

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.12.3
control plane version: 1.12.3
data plane version: 1.12.3 (58 proxies)

#  kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.22.6
Server Version: v1.22.6

# containerd --version
containerd containerd.io 1.6.6

# calico version  v3.23.1 

# iptables --version
iptables v1.4.21

# uname -a
Linux k8snode26 4.20.13-1.el7.elrepo.x86_64 #1 SMP Wed Feb 27 10:02:05 EST 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```


### Additional Information

I used some tools and found the following information, but I don't know what happened.

When using the top command, you can see that wa is very large:
![top](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25141522/173768472-18652554-a05a-41de-b254-e5ae612ede85.png)

At this time, using iotop, you can see that the disk read speed of pilot is 140M/s:
![iotop](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25141522/173768808-01e2001a-b5bf-4b1d-8693-7a5ba22f455e.png)

Then use the `pidstat -dt -p 17544 1` command to see which child thread frequently operates io:
![pidstat](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25141522/173785357-4821406d-a01d-426a-9e7b-3918a82a2f3c.png)

Finally, through `perf trace -t 17558`, the 17558 thread was found and the following information was printed:
![rt_sigre](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25141522/173785689-33d59a33-2590-4b6e-b8b7-3a29834614eb.png)

After the server IO is raised, the information of `rt_sigreturn `will be printed, but I don't know what the error is.

comment.body:

If you feel this issue or pull request deserves attention, please reopen the issue. Please see [this wiki page](https://github.com/istio/istio/wiki/Issue-and-Pull-Request-Lifecycle-Manager) for more information. Thank you for your contributions.

issue.title: Start with development help: trying to just make fails with "make[1]: dirname: Operation not permitted"

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

I am trying to start development on a feature and run tests, but so far this is not off to a good start:

steps attempted:
- followed guide [here](https://github.com/istio/istio/wiki/Preparing-for-Development)
- added tag and user
- tried cloning repo fresh in case of permissions problem
- running make invariably runs into this issue:

```code
# make
make
make[1]: dirname: Operation not permitted
make[1]: /bin/bash: Operation not permitted
make[1]: /bin/bash: Operation not permitted
make[1]: /bin/bash: Operation not permitted

issue.title: Istio sending external http traffic to blackhole when address ends with .local and DNS_PROXY and AUTO_ALLOCATION is enabled

labels.name: lifecycle/stale

issue.body:
### Bug Description

1. Enable DNS_PROXY and AUTO_ALLOCATION
2. Create a service entry for a HTTP service. 
3. 
```
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  name: istio-test
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  hosts:
  - external.resource.obs
  location: MESH_EXTERNAL
  ports:
  - name: test
    number: 80
    protocol: HTTP
  resolution: DNS
```
In some clusters,  trying to reach the external service returns a 502 from envoy when running curl from the application container. The request is successful when curling from the istio-proxy though. 

```
* Connected to external.resource.obs (240.240.0.31) port 80 (#0)
> GET / HTTP/1.1
> Host: external.resource.obs
> User-Agent: curl/7.79.1
> Accept: */*
>
* Mark bundle as not supporting multiuse
< HTTP/1.1 502 Bad Gateway
< date: Sun, 05 Jun 2022 22:47:29 GMT
< server: envoy
< content-length: 0
<
* Connection #0 to host external.resource.obs left intact
```

```

    "upstream_transport_failure_reason": null,
    "upstream_host": null,

}

    "istio_policy_status": null,
    "authority": "external.resource.obs",
    "bytes_sent": 0,
    "x_forwarded_for": null,
    "upstream_host": null,
    "response_flags": "-",
    "upstream_cluster": null,
    "response_code": 502,

    "upstream_transport_failure_reason": null,
    "upstream_local_address": null,
    "path": "/",
    "method": "GET",
    "protocol": "HTTP/1.1",
    "user_agent": "curl/7.79.1",
    "start_time": "2022-06-05T22:57:04.020Z",

```

If you change the service protocol to TCP things start working.

issue.title: Tunnel client TLS to gateway using mTLS issue

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

[ Istio 1.13.4 ]

I'm trying to get a client-originated TLS connection to tunnel to an egress gateway using Istio mTLS so that `AuthorizationPolicy` can be applied in the gateway to permit authorized workloads to connect to the hosts managed by the gateway. Istio-originated TLS at the gateway works fine but in this use-case I need client-originated to work.

The flow I'd like to achieve is this:

```
client ->(TLS)-> envoy ->(mTLS-over-TLS)-> gateway ->(TLS)-> external host
```

Firstly, passthrough TLS (without mTLS) is working fine and I can see from the client and gateway logs that the call is correctly routed but obviously there is no mTLS so no possibility to authorize the calling workload at the gateway. For reference, here's my starting passthrough configuration that works:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: Gateway
metadata:
  name: istio-egress-int-https
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  selector:
    istio: egressgateway
  servers:
    - hosts:
      - andybrown.me.uk
      port:
        number: 443
        name: tls-passthrough
        protocol: TLS
      tls:
        mode: PASSTHROUGH
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: DestinationRule
metadata:
  name: andy-gateway
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  host: istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
  subsets:
  - name: andy
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  name: andy
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  location: MESH_EXTERNAL
  hosts: [ "andybrown.me.uk" ]
  ports:
  - number: 443
    name: tls-andy
    protocol: TLS
  resolution: DNS
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: andy
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  hosts:
    - andybrown.me.uk
  gateways:
    - mesh
    - istio-egress-int-https
  tls:

    - match:
        - gateways:
            - mesh
          port: 443
          sniHosts:
            - andybrown.me.uk

      route:
        - destination:
            host: istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
            subset: andy
            port:
              number: 443

    - match:
        - gateways:
            - istio-egress-int-https
          port: 443
          sniHosts:
            - andybrown.me.uk

      route:
        - destination:
            host: andybrown.me.uk
            port:
              number: 443
          weight: 100
```

To upgrade to mTLS between the client and the gateway I tried to change the gateway server to `ISTIO_MUTUAL` and again for the port in the gateway's `DestinationRule` like this:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: Gateway
metadata:
  name: istio-egress-int-https
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  selector:
    istio: egressgateway
  servers:
    - hosts:
      - andybrown.me.uk
      port:
        number: 443
        name: tls-passthrough
        protocol: TLS
      tls:
        mode: ISTIO_MUTUAL
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: DestinationRule
metadata:
  name: andy-gateway
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  host: istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
  subsets:
  - name: andy
    trafficPolicy:
      loadBalancer:
        simple: ROUND_ROBIN
      tls:
        mode: ISTIO_MUTUAL
        sni: andybrown.me.uk
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  name: andy
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  location: MESH_EXTERNAL
  hosts: [ "andybrown.me.uk" ]
  ports:
  - number: 443
    name: tls-andy
    protocol: TLS
  resolution: DNS
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: andy
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  hosts:
    - andybrown.me.uk
  gateways:
    - mesh
    - istio-egress-int-https
  tls:

    - match:
        - gateways:
            - mesh
          port: 443
          sniHosts:
            - andybrown.me.uk

      route:
        - destination:
            host: istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
            subset: andy
            port:
              number: 443

    - match:
        - gateways:
            - istio-egress-int-https
          port: 443
          sniHosts:
            - andybrown.me.uk

      route:
        - destination:
            host: andybrown.me.uk
            port:
              number: 443
          weight: 100
```
Now I get an error in the client pod when I test it with `curl`:
```
curl: (35) OpenSSL SSL_connect: SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL in connection to andybrown.me.uk:443
```
A log entry appears in the client envoy container:
```
[2022-05-31T17:57:36.941Z] "- - -" 0 UF,URX - - "-" 0 0 11 - "-" "-" "-" "-" "10.0.201.112:8443" outbound|443|andy|istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local - 240.240.0.2:443 10.0.148.235:52822 andybrown.me.uk -
```
Nothing appears in the gateway logs so I increased the client envoy logs to `debug` and saw this when a connection attempt is made by the client:
```
envoy filter    tls inspector: new connection accepted
envoy filter    tls:onServerName(), requestedServerName: andybrown.me.uk
envoy filter    [C12783] new tcp proxy session
envoy filter    [C12783] Creating connection to cluster outbound|443|andy|istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
envoy misc      Allocating TCP conn pool
envoy pool      trying to create new connection
envoy pool      creating a new connection
envoy connection        [C12784] connecting to 10.0.201.112:8443
envoy connection        [C12784] connection in progress
envoy conn_handler      [C12783] new connection from 10.0.148.235:52872
envoy connection        [C12784] delayed connect error: 111
envoy connection        [C12784] closing socket: 0
envoy connection        [C12784] TLS error: 268435588:SSL routines:OPENSSL_internal:CLIENTHELLO_TLSEXT 268435646:SSL routines:OPENSSL_internal:PARSE_TLSEXT
envoy pool      [C12784] client disconnected, failure reason: delayed connect error: 111
envoy filter    [C12783] Creating connection to cluster outbound|443|andy|istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
envoy connection        [C12783] closing data_to_write=0 type=1
envoy connection        [C12783] closing socket: 1
```
I have verified that `10.0.201.112` is the pod IP of the egress gateway. This is where I'm stuck. Can anyone advise on what I need to configure to make this work? I've shown just one target host here but the solution needs to be extendable for multiple external hosts through this gateway.

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.13.4
control plane version: 1.13.4
data plane version: 1.13.4 (10 proxies)

$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.24.0
Kustomize Version: v4.5.4
Server Version: v1.24.0
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

      port:
        number: 443
        name: tls-passthrough
        protocol: TLS
      tls:
        mode: ISTIO_MUTUAL
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: DestinationRule
metadata:
  name: andy-gateway
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  host: istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
  subsets:
  - name: andy
    trafficPolicy:
      loadBalancer:
        simple: ROUND_ROBIN
      tls:
        mode: ISTIO_MUTUAL
        sni: andybrown.me.uk
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  name: andy
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  location: MESH_EXTERNAL
  hosts: [ "andybrown.me.uk" ]
  ports:
  - number: 443
    name: tls-andy
    protocol: TLS
  resolution: DNS
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: andy
  namespace: istio-egress-int-https
spec:
  hosts:
    - andybrown.me.uk
  gateways:
    - mesh
    - istio-egress-int-https
  tls:

    - match:
        - gateways:
            - mesh
          port: 443
          sniHosts:
            - andybrown.me.uk

      route:
        - destination:
            host: istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
            subset: andy
            port:
              number: 443

    - match:
        - gateways:
            - istio-egress-int-https
          port: 443
          sniHosts:
            - andybrown.me.uk

      route:
        - destination:
            host: andybrown.me.uk
            port:
              number: 443
          weight: 100
```
Now I get an error in the client pod when I test it with `curl`:
```
curl: (35) OpenSSL SSL_connect: SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL in connection to andybrown.me.uk:443
```
A log entry appears in the client envoy container:
```
[2022-05-31T17:57:36.941Z] "- - -" 0 UF,URX - - "-" 0 0 11 - "-" "-" "-" "-" "10.0.201.112:8443" outbound|443|andy|istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local - 240.240.0.2:443 10.0.148.235:52822 andybrown.me.uk -
```
Nothing appears in the gateway logs so I increased the client envoy logs to `debug` and saw this when a connection attempt is made by the client:
```
envoy filter    tls inspector: new connection accepted
envoy filter    tls:onServerName(), requestedServerName: andybrown.me.uk
envoy filter    [C12783] new tcp proxy session
envoy filter    [C12783] Creating connection to cluster outbound|443|andy|istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
envoy misc      Allocating TCP conn pool
envoy pool      trying to create new connection
envoy pool      creating a new connection
envoy connection        [C12784] connecting to 10.0.201.112:8443
envoy connection        [C12784] connection in progress
envoy conn_handler      [C12783] new connection from 10.0.148.235:52872
envoy connection        [C12784] delayed connect error: 111
envoy connection        [C12784] closing socket: 0
envoy connection        [C12784] TLS error: 268435588:SSL routines:OPENSSL_internal:CLIENTHELLO_TLSEXT 268435646:SSL routines:OPENSSL_internal:PARSE_TLSEXT
envoy pool      [C12784] client disconnected, failure reason: delayed connect error: 111
envoy filter    [C12783] Creating connection to cluster outbound|443|andy|istio-egress-int-https.istio-egress-int-https.svc.cluster.local
envoy connection        [C12783] closing data_to_write=0 type=1
envoy connection        [C12783] closing socket: 1
```
I have verified that `10.0.201.112` is the pod IP of the egress gateway. This is where I'm stuck. Can anyone advise on what I need to configure to make this work? I've shown just one target host here but the solution needs to be extendable for multiple external hosts through this gateway.

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.13.4
control plane version: 1.13.4
data plane version: 1.13.4 (10 proxies)

$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.24.0
Kustomize Version: v4.5.4
Server Version: v1.24.0
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: Missing calls to external services in the istio-proxy logs

labels.name: lifecycle/stale

issue.body:
I open this issue since we are not able to find a documentation or example about this. From our logs, in particular about the egress logs, it seems that there are missing log lines about the egress call our system does to an external service. For example, we expect to see 4k calls to our database, but we see around 200 calls per minute in the `istio-proxy` log. Is there a default trace sampling value to change in order to check this thing?
We are on 1.13.3 istio version.

Indeed we see a mismatch between the newrelic monitor dashboards and the `istio-proxy` logs.

We tested adding the annotation to the deployment but no results:
```
proxy.istio.io/config: '{ "tracing": { "sampling": 100} }'
```
this should be the same of the example described in the section [https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/observability/distributed-tracing/mesh-and-proxy-config/#using-proxy-istio-io-confi[…]notation-for-trace-settings](https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/observability/distributed-tracing/mesh-and-proxy-config/#using-proxy-istio-io-config-annotation-for-trace-settings).

Currently, our configuration has the following envoyfilter logs:
```
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3

issue.title: Having `filter_chain_not_found` when service port is different than container port
issue.body:
### Bug Description

I've applied on a fresh install (it does behave "normally" on upgraded clusters) https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/security/authentication/authn-policy/#setup in order to have some pods / services

from a sleep pod:

```
/ $ curl http://httpbin.foo:8000/ip
upstream connect error or disconnect/reset before headers. reset reason: connection termination/ $
/ $ curl http://httpbin.bar:8000/ip
upstream connect error or disconnect/reset before headers. reset reason: connection termination/ $
/ $ curl http://httpbin:8000/ip
upstream connect error or disconnect/reset before headers. reset reason: connection termination/ $
/ $ curl http://httpbin.foo.svc.cluster.local:8000/ip
upstream connect error or disconnect/reset before headers. reset reason: connection termination/ $
```

service is following:

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  annotations:
    kubectl.kubernetes.io/last-applied-configuration: |
      {"apiVersion":"v1","kind":"Service","metadata":{"annotations":{},"labels":{"app":"httpbin","service":"httpbin"},"name":"httpbin","namespace":"foo"},"spec":{"ports":[{"name":"http","port":8000,"targetPort":80}],"selector":{"app":"httpbin"}}}
  creationTimestamp: "2022-09-06T18:46:41Z"
  labels:
    app: httpbin
    service: httpbin
  name: httpbin
  namespace: foo
  resourceVersion: "277501"
  uid: 5b5a4f3e-68ec-4a7f-a2f1-5ef7fc8c8a41
spec:
  clusterIP: 10.43.75.98
  clusterIPs:
  - 10.43.75.98
  internalTrafficPolicy: Cluster
  ipFamilies:
  - IPv4
  ipFamilyPolicy: SingleStack
  ports:
  - name: http
    port: 8000
    protocol: TCP
    targetPort: 80
  selector:
    app: httpbin
  sessionAffinity: None
  type: ClusterIP
status:
  loadBalancer: {}
```

now I edit service httpbin of ns foo so that svc port is also 80:

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  annotations:
    kubectl.kubernetes.io/last-applied-configuration: |
      {"apiVersion":"v1","kind":"Service","metadata":{"annotations":{},"labels":{"app":"httpbin","service":"httpbin"},"name":"httpbin","namespace":"foo"},"spec":{"ports":[{"name":"http","port":8000,"targetPort":80}],"selector":{"app":"httpbin"}}}
  creationTimestamp: "2022-09-06T18:46:41Z"
  labels:
    app: httpbin
    service: httpbin
  name: httpbin
  namespace: foo
  resourceVersion: "282356"
  uid: 5b5a4f3e-68ec-4a7f-a2f1-5ef7fc8c8a41
spec:
  clusterIP: 10.43.75.98
  clusterIPs:
  - 10.43.75.98
  internalTrafficPolicy: Cluster
  ipFamilies:
  - IPv4
  ipFamilyPolicy: SingleStack
  ports:
  - name: http
    port: 80
    protocol: TCP
    targetPort: 80
  selector:
    app: httpbin
  sessionAffinity: None
  type: ClusterIP
status:
  loadBalancer: {}
```

now everything works on istio side:

```
/ $ curl http://httpbin.foo.svc.cluster.local/ip
{
  "origin": "127.0.0.6"
}
/ $ curl http://httpbin.foo/ip
{
  "origin": "127.0.0.6"
}
/ $
```

putting it back results to same behavior :(

I've tested on k8s `1.23` and `1.24` and also istio `1.14.3` and `1.15.0`.

On older deployments (using k8s `1.23` or `1.22` and installed with istio `1.12.x`, `1.13.x` or `1.14.1` and then upgraded  to latest istio), everything works like a charm 🤯.

and traffic from ingress is also fine 😮.

### Version

```prose
installation is done via flux using helm


$ istioctl version
client version: 1.12.7
control plane version: 1.15.0
data plane version: 1.15.0 (27 proxies)

$ kubectl version --short
Flag --short has been deprecated, and will be removed in the future. The --short output will become the default.
Client Version: v1.25.0
Kustomize Version: v4.5.7
Server Version: v1.24.4+rke2r1

$ flux: v0.33.0
helm-controller: v0.23.1
kustomize-controller: v0.27.1
notification-controller: v0.25.2
source-controller: v0.28.0
```


### Additional Information

[bug-report.tar.gz](https://github.com/istio/istio/files/9500201/bug-report.tar.gz)


here's the override file for istio:

global:
  istiod:
    enableAnalysis: true
```

        address: jaeger-collector-mtls.tracing.svc.cluster.local:9411
  enablePrometheusMerge: false
  enableTracing: true
  extensionProviders:
  - envoyExtAuthzHttp:
      headersToDownstreamOnDeny:

      headersToUpstreamOnAllow:
      - authorization

      - X-Auth-Request-Access-Token

      - X-Auth-Request-Preferred-Username
      - Access-Control-Allow-Origin
      - path
      - cookie
      - X-Real-IP
      - X-B3-TraceId
      - X-B3-ParentSpanId
      - X-B3-SpanId
      - x-request-id
      - x-b3-sampled
      - x-b3-flags
      includeAdditionalHeadersInCheck:
        X-Auth-Request-Redirect: 'https://%REQ(Host)%'
      includeHeadersInCheck:
      - cookie
      - authorization
      port: 80
      service: oauth2-proxy.oauth2-proxy.svc.cluster.local
    name: oauth2-proxy
  rootNamespace: istio-system

issue.title: Cross cluster traffic will encounter connection problem when one of the cluster has nodes scale-in

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

We have 2 AWS EKS clusters with self-managed nodes in 2 different network (2 VPCs with peering connection setup properly), and istio is deployed as:

-  multi-cluster
- multi-network
- multi-control-plane
- single mesh

It's working properly most of the time, but when one of the cluster has a nodes scale-in (only scale-in, adding nodes won't affect this), either taken out by auto-scaling-group policy or manually, the cross cluster traffic would encounter a connection problem. If `http.retries.perTryTimeout` is set, the connection will be retried after the timeout. This situation will be auto-resolved after some time, typically 17 mins.

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.13.5
control plane version: 1.13.5
data plane version: 1.13.5

$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.21.2
Server Version: v1.21.14-eks-6d3986b
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: Histogram metric for Istio sidecar processing delay

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
(This is used to request new product features, please visit <https://discuss.istio.io> for questions on using Istio)

**Describe the feature request**

I wonder if it is possible to expose a histogram metric for **processing delay** in Istio sidecar. I understand currently we already have upstream service time and request duration available in access log, and request duration available in sidecar metric. We however cannot deduce the processing delay (introduced by JWT validation, ratelimit decision and other envoyFilter functionalities) from metric directly. The value `request duration - upstream service time` calculated from access log cannot correctly reflect the processing time either (it includes the network delay).

It would be great if such processing delay can be included in the metrics exposed by Istio or its sidecar with standard tagging.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

A quick alternative solution is to export a custom histogram metric deduced from `request duration - upstream service time` from Istio sidecar using [stats config](https://istio.io/latest/docs/reference/config/proxy_extensions/stats/), but I don't know exactly how to achieve this by reading the documentation.

issue.title: istioctl analyze: showing invalid error on release 1.13.2

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

labels.name: kind/istioctl
labels.description: Related to istioctl commands.

issue.body:
### Bug Description

On the same cluster when running same command 
`istioctl analyze -A`

When the istioctl version is 1.13.2 it is showing the following as a error in the result:
`Error [IST0101] (Gateway istio-system/istio-ingressgateway) Referenced selector not found: "istio=ingressgateway"`

But when istioctl version is 1.12.2 it not showing anything as such.

Upon manual verification of the cluster the error looks to invalid. And all traffic are working fine in the cluster.

Upon verification of one of the gateway pod I can see the label:
```
$ kubectl describe pod istio-ingressgateway-abcd -n istio-system
Labels:       
              istio=ingressgateway
```
Also Istioctl validate does not seems to show any issues:
```
kubectl get gw istio-ingressgateway -n istio-system -o yaml | istioctl validate -f –
kubectl get deployments -o yaml -n istio-system | istioctl validate -f –
kubectl get services -o yaml -n istio-system | istioctl validate -f –
kubectl get pods -o yaml -n istio-system | istioctl validate -f –
```

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.13.2
control plane version: 1.13.2
data plane version: 1.13.2 (9 proxies)

$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.21.0
Server Version: v1.21.9
```


### Additional Information

Related to:
https://github.com/istio/istio/issues/36160

issue.title: Single Rate limit bucket with weighted request to consume tokens.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
Hi Everyone

I have one query related local rate limit. We have a use case where different APIs holds different response/processing time. For example Bulk APIs vs Single Item API .
We want to utilise local rate limit , one way is having different token buckets with respect to APIs and let them get processed independently.
However as we can’t guarantee incoming traffic ratio ( Bulk APIs calls vs Light calls) we may end up in situation where one bucket is exhausted and other one still active.
I am looking for alternative Option where same bucket can be leveraged for multiple APIs and we can assign weights to APIs path . For example:
Say we have 100 Tokens , Assign weights to APIs :
API v1 weight → 1
API v2 weight → 2

On invocation of v1 light weight API Single token should be consumed on the other hand on invocation of v2 API 2 tokens would be consumed.Can we achieve something similar where same bucket can be shared across APIs with different token consumption rate?

issue.title: HTTP2 on the mesh for HTTP/1.1 upstream destination?

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
Is there a way to configure Istio to use HTTP2 for communication between the sidecars EVEN if the services are not able to consume HTTP2 yet?

Basically something like this:

```Client <---http/1.1--> Istio-gateway <-- http2 --> Istio-Sidecar <--http/1.1-->Upstream service.```

[This should work with the right configuration on Envoy I believe](https://www.envoyproxy.io/docs/envoy/latest/intro/arch_overview/http/upgrades). Is there any way to configure this on Istio?

I believe that the `h2UpradePolicy` only works if the Upstream service is also able to consume http2, isn't?

We are trying to solve a corner-case where we are getting hit by a very large amount of new connections and requests at the same time on our gateways. Because of HTTP/1.1 HoL blocking limitations, the Gateway opens a large amount of new connections to the istio-sidecar in order to multiplex all the new requests. All those new connections coming up at once create some instability on the sidecar for a couple seconds (to process the high cost of new connection establishment). HTTP2 would solve this but our upstream service doesn't seem to accept it yet.

### Version

```prose
istiod 1.14.3
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: [istioctl] cluster connection configuration options

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
**Describe the feature request**
Currently istioctl accept kubeconfig file location as option via `--kubeconfig`.
We need other options that allow to pass cluster connection configuration as string, just like kubectl options ( `--cluster`, `--context`, `--user`, `--token`, ....).

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Something like --kubeconfigValue to pass the entire kubeconfig as string.

issue.title: Add Sidecar validation for duplicate hosts on port

labels.name: size/S
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 10-29 lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
When creating EgressListeners on a Sidecar resource, the validation webhook will prevent multiple listeners with the same port. If a single EgressListener is specified with multiple hosts against one port then this is not flagged even though the listener is IP bound and the proxy configuration pushed will only contain one listener.

This PR brings the single EgressListener, multiple hosts and one port case in line with the multiple EgressListeners, each with one host and one port and returns the same validation error to the client.

pull_request.title: Add Sidecar validation for duplicate hosts on port
pull_request.body:
When creating EgressListeners on a Sidecar resource, the validation webhook will prevent multiple listeners with the same port. If a single EgressListener is specified with multiple hosts against one port then this is not flagged even though the listener is IP bound and the proxy configuration pushed will only contain one listener.

This PR brings the single EgressListener, multiple hosts and one port case in line with the multiple EgressListeners, each with one host and one port and returns the same validation error to the client.

issue.title: When using external profile install or generate manifest duplicate services and endpoints created.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

When use the following command to generate manifest file, duplicate istiod service and endpoint will be produced.

```
cat <<EOF | istioctl manifest generate -f -
apiVersion: install.istio.io/v1alpha1
kind: IstioOperator
spec:
  profile: external
  values:
    global:
      remotePilotAddress: 1.2.3.4
    istiodRemote:
      injectionPath: /inject/cluster/cluster2/net/network1
  components:
    base:
      enabled: true
EOF
```

The following services will be duplicated in the output.

```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Endpoints
metadata:
  name: istiod
  namespace: istio-system
subsets:
- addresses:
  - ip: 1.2.3.4
  ports:
  - port: 15012
    name: tcp-istiod
    protocol: TCP
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: istiod
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  ports:
  - port: 15012
    name: tcp-istiod
    protocol: TCP
  # if the remotePilotAddress is IP addr, we use clusterIP: None.
  # else, we use externalName
  clusterIP: None
```

using k8s overlay can only modify one instance.


### Version

```prose
This error exists in the following releases tested.
1.13.x
1.14.x
1.15 (master local build)
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: Allow to configure LoadBalancerClass for service in gateway helm chart

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
**Describe the feature request**
I want to set the `spec.loadBalancerClass` of the Service in the gateway helm chart, see [Specifying class of load balancer implementation](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/service/#load-balancer-class).

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Use annotations on the Service to select load balancer implementation.

**Affected product area (please put an X in all that apply)**

[ ] Test and Release
[ ] User Experience

[ ] Multi Control Plane

**Additional context**
The AWS Load Balancer Controller supports this field to select the load balancer controller instead of the in-tree controller. The `spec.loadBalancerClass` field was added in kubernetes v1.22.

issue.title: Fix pure client locality label retrieval
issue.body:
**Please provide a description of this PR:**
I realised that a _'pure client'_ sleep pod was not balancing traffic as expected.
Non-pure clients were doing it fine, though.
Turns out the locality labels where not propagated from `.spec.template.metadata.labels.istio-locality`.
This patch fixes the label retrieval.

On the other hand, my initial expectation was that pure-clients where able to discover `region/zone/subzone` from the underlying node without having to set an explicit `istio-locality` label. I might be missing something, if anyone can throw some light it would be great.

issue.title: Don't trigger pushes when updating K8s service annotations not releated to istio
issue.body:
(This is used to request new product features, please visit <https://discuss.istio.io> for questions on using Istio)

**Describe the feature request**
When I add annotation `a: b` to a K8s service, pilot will trigger ADS pushes to all clients.

I think it's unnecessary to trigger pushes if the updated annotations are not releated to istio.

Otherwise, batch updates on service annotations will make the pilot consume more CPU.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

issue.title: Deployment cannot be created again with the same name in IstioOperator

labels.name: area/environments/operator
labels.description: Issues related to Operator or installation

issue.body:
### Bug Description

sample yaml (iop-test.yaml):
```
apiVersion: install.istio.io/v1alpha1
kind: IstioOperator
metadata:
  name: ingressgw-test
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  components:
    ingressGateways:
    - enabled: true
      k8s:
        replicaCount: 1
        resources:
          limits:
            cpu: "0.2"
            memory: 200Mi
          requests:
            cpu: "0.2"
            memory: 200Mi
      label:
        app: ingressgw-test
        istio: tuhao-test-ingressgw-test
      name: ingressgw-test
      namespace: tuhao-test
  profile: empty
  revision: 1-10
  values:
    gateways:
      istio-ingressgateway:
        autoscaleEnabled: false
        injectionTemplate: gateway
        replicaCount: 1
```

Reproduce steps:
1. `kubuectl apply -f iop-test.yaml`
2. wait for deployment and pod to be created
3. delete the deployment
4. repeat the first step

Expect:
deployment will be created again

Actual:
no deployment created.(you must change `ingressgw-test` to another name in iop-test.yaml) 


### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.10.5
control plane version: 1.10.5-v3.7.5
data plane version: 1.10.5-v3.7.5 (10 proxies)
$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.21.4
Server Version: v1.21.4
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: high cpu usage for workload entry registration

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

labels.name: lifecycle/automatically-closed
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue that has been closed automatically.

labels.name: feature/Virtual-machine
labels.description: issues related with VM support

issue.body:
**Bug description**
Istio CPU usage is high when there is a large amount of workload entry registration.

For example, istiod pod was throttled by cpu limit (8 cpu cores), when workload entry was created at QPS of 1k/s, uniformly distributed among 1k namespaces.


[ ] Configuration Infrastructure
[ ] Docs
[ ] Installation
[ ] Networking
[x] Performance and Scalability
[ ] Policies and Telemetry
[ ] Security
[ ] Test and Release
[ ] User Experience
[ ] Developer Infrastructure



**Expected behavior**
Pilot can handle registration of appropriate number of WorkloadEntry instances, and gracefully handles high churn of WorkloadEntry instances.

**Steps to reproduce the bug**
wrote a simple program to concurrently create workload entry at 1k/s QPS, uniformly under 1k namespaces.

have we done any perf testing as the test plan mentioned in the [design doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/10TyPy-6bOs0_7JljGpc2RneDdsaR9GktjwwaaVbz6fs/edit#).

I also followed the instruction [here](https://github.com/istio/istio/wiki/Analyzing-Istio-Performance) and did some cpu profiling. 
[pprof.pilot-discovery.samples.cpu.003.pb.gz](https://github.com/istio/istio/files/4748775/pprof.pilot-discovery.samples.cpu.003.pb.gz)



**Version (include the output of `istioctl version --remote` and `kubectl version` and `helm version` if you used Helm)**
```
istioctl version --remote
client version: 1.6.0
control plane version: 1.6.0
data plane version: none
```

```
kubectl version
Client Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"18", GitVersion:"v1.18.2", GitCommit:"52c56ce7a8272c798dbc29846288d7cd9fbae032", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2020-04-16T23:35:15Z", GoVersion:"go1.14.2", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"darwin/amd64"}
Server Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"15+", GitVersion:"v1.15.12-airbnb0", GitCommit:"da578f6bba72b15d934dd1a9d53acbc2c61863e7", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2020-05-27T13:58:10Z", GoVersion:"go1.12.17", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}
```

**How was Istio installed?**
istioctl to generate manifest
kubectl to apply generated yamls
istio operator to do the actual work

**Environment where bug was observed (cloud vendor, OS, etc)**
AWS, AL2
